A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The stabilizer or isotropy subgroup of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G_{x}:=\{g \in G ; g x=x\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Stabilizer to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Associative Law pertains to the operation within a set, ensuring that the order of operations does not affect the outcome. This law is fundamental in the definition of a group, as it is one of the group axioms. A group is defined as a set equipped with a binary operation that is associative, has an identity element, and where every element has an inverse.

The concept of a Stabilizer involves a group acting on a set. The definition of a stabilizer does not explicitly require the Associative Law; it focuses on the elements of the group that leave a particular element of the set unchanged. However, the underlying group operation, which is part of the action, implicitly requires the Associative Law because the group itself must be associative as per its definition.

Therefore, while the definition of a stabilizer does not directly state the need for the Associative Law, the existence and properties of the group (which include associativity) are essential for the concept of a stabilizer to be well-defined and meaningful.
